<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>The Smishing Deluge: China-Based Campaign Flooding Global Text Messages</title>
	<meta name="description" content="Global smishing activity tracked by Unit 42 includes impersonation of many critical services. Its unique ecosystem allows attackers to quickly scale." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-smishing-campaign/" />

	<meta property="og:description" content="Global smishing activity tracked by Unit 42 includes impersonation of many critical services. Its unique ecosystem allows attackers to quickly scale." />
	<meta property="og:url" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-smishing-campaign/" />

<meta property="og:author" content="Chi-Wei Liu"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content="phishing,smishing,SMS,social engineering"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"The Smishing Deluge: China-Based Campaign Flooding Global Text Messages","name":"The Smishing Deluge: China-Based Campaign Flooding Global Text Messages","description":"Global smishing activity tracked by Unit 42 includes impersonation of many critical services. Its unique ecosystem allows attackers to quickly scale.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/global-smishing-campaign\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/global-smishing-campaign\/","datePublished":"October 23, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nWe are attributing an ongoing smishing (phishing via text message) campaign of fraudulent toll violation and package misdelivery notices to a group widely known as the Smishing Triad. Our analysis indicates this campaign is a significantly more extensive and complex threat than previously reported. Attackers have impersonated international services across a wide array of critical sectors.\r\n\r\nThe attackers have targeted U.S. residents in this campaign since April 2024. The threat actor is evolving their tactics by expanding their reach globally, improving the social engineering tactics used in smishing for delivery.\r\n\r\nThe threat actor is also expanding the range of services they impersonate to include many international services in critical sectors, such as:\r\n\r\n \tBanking\r\n \tCryptocurrency platforms\r\n \tE-commerce platforms\r\n \tHealthcare\r\n \tLaw enforcement\r\n \tSocial media\r\n\r\nThe campaign is highly decentralized, lacking a single point of control, and uses a large number of domains and a diverse set of hosting infrastructure. This is advantageous for the attackers as churning through thousands of domains weekly makes detection more difficult.\r\n\r\nUsing our intelligence framework, we have identified over 194,000 malicious domains linked to this operation since Jan. 1, 2024. Although these domains are registered through a Hong Kong-based registrar and use Chinese nameservers, the attack infrastructure is primarily hosted on popular U.S. cloud services.\r\n\r\nThis campaign uses SMS messages for social engineering to create a sense of urgency and prompt victims into immediate action. The campaign's global scale, complex infrastructure and realistic phishing pages strongly suggest that it is powered by a large, well-resourced phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) operation. This poses a widespread threat to individuals globally. These phishing pages aim to collect sensitive information such as National Identification Numbers (such as Social Security numbers), home addresses, payment details and login credentials.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nPhishing, SMS\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTechnical Analysis of the Extended Smishing Triad Campaign\r\nEarlier this year, we released timely threat intelligence social posts that reported our discovery of more than 10,000 domains involved in smishing scams. Subsequently, we found and blocked over 91,500 domains involved in the same scam. Since publishing those threat intelligence posts, we have continued to track and analyze the threat actors and domains behind these smishing scams.\r\n\r\nSecurity vendor Resecurity attributes these attacks to the Smishing Triad, reporting that the group shared phishing kits on Telegram and other services. This finding is corroborated by follow-up reports by Silent Push. However, our analysis reveals that the campaign's scope is far broader and evolves faster than previously known.\r\n\r\nMany indicators suggest that the campaign is constantly evolving. A Fortinet article highlighted the fact that the threat actors used email-to-SMS features. This article noted that arbitrary email addresses can be used to send messages through iMessage. However, we have observed that more recent smishing messages have started to use phone numbers to send them.\r\n\r\nMany of these messages are received from phone numbers beginning with the international country code for the Philippines (+63). However, there has been an increasing number of messages in this campaign received from U.S. phone numbers (+1) as well.\r\n\r\nTracking all domains in this campaign is challenging due to its decentralized nature. The attack domains are short-lived and constantly churned, with thousands registered daily. The rapidly evolving campaign highlights that tracking root domains using just lexical patterns is not enough.\r\n\r\nWe have developed a multi-faceted intelligence framework to track this campaign. It synthesizes data from the following sources:\r\n\r\n \tWHOIS and passive DNS (pDNS) reputation metrics\r\n \tEvolving domain patterns\r\n \tVisual clustering of screenshots\r\n \tGraph-based infrastructure analysis\r\n\r\nUsing our multi-faceted intelligence framework, we found a total of 194,345 fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) across 136,933 root domains associated with this campaign. These root domains were registered on or after Jan. 1, 2024.\r\n\r\nThe majority of these domains are registered through Dominet (HK) Limited, a Hong Kong-based registrar and use Chinese nameservers. Although the domain registration and DNS infrastructure originate in China, the attacking infrastructure (the hosting IP addresses) is concentrated in the U.S., particularly within popular cloud services.\r\n\r\nWe find that the domains in this campaign impersonate global services in many sectors, including:\r\n\r\n \tCritical services: Banking, healthcare and law enforcement (e.g., multi-national financial services and investment companies, police forces from cities in the Middle East)\r\n \tWidely used services: E-commerce, social media, online gaming and cryptocurrency exchanges (e.g., several Russia-based e-commerce markets and cryptocurrency exchanges)\r\n \tPreviously reported services: Tolls and global state-owned mail and package delivery services extending beyond the U.S. (e.g., Israel, Canada, France, Germany, Ireland, Australia, Argentina)\r\n\r\nAttackers craft SMS messages to deliver these URLs. These are highly tailored to the victims to compel immediate action. Using social engineering techniques creates a sense of urgency. By employing targeted personal information and incorporating technical or legal jargon they can appear more legitimate. These things combined with the scope of services imitated suggests that a large PhaaS operation is behind this campaign.\r\nUnderground Phishing-as-a-Service Ecosystem\r\nIn this section, we discuss the underground PhaaS ecosystem and investigate the Smishing Triad Telegram channel. Over the past six months, the channel has evolved from a dedicated phishing kit marketplace into a highly active community that gathers diverse threat actors within the PhaaS ecosystem.\r\n\r\nFigure 1 shows chat records from different participants within the channel. Most posts are advertising various underground services such as domain registration, data sales and message delivery. Highlighting the intense competition within this ecosystem, multiple threat actors compete to offer the same services, particularly Rich Communication Services and Instant Message delivery (RCS\/IM).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161932\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Telegram chat history of different threat actors in the PhaaS ecosystem.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 2 illustrates below the different roles active in the Smishing Triad Telegram channel and their interactions.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161943\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. The PhaaS ecosystem of the Smishing Triad.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThreat actors specialize in different stages of the smishing supply chain, enabling them to launch attacks more efficiently and scalably:\r\n\r\n \tUpstream\r\n\r\n \tData broker: Sells target phone numbers\r\n \tDomain seller: Registers disposable domains for hosting phishing websites\r\n \tHosting provider: Provides servers to run phishing backends\r\n\r\n\r\n \tMidstream\r\n\r\n \tPhishing kit developer: Builds phishing websites (frontend and backend) and maintains the PhaaS platform, including dashboards for harvesting and managing stolen credentials\r\n\r\n\r\n \tDownstream\r\n\r\n \tSMS\/RCS\/IM spammer: Delivers phishing messages at scale to direct victims to phishing websites\r\n\r\n\r\n \tSupport\r\n\r\n \tLiveness scanner: Verifies which target phone numbers are valid and active\r\n \tBlocklist scanner: Checks the phishing domains against blocklists to trigger asset rotations\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDomains Involved in the Campaign\r\nA majority of the root domains involved in this campaign were created with a hyphenated series of strings followed by a top-level domain (TLD) (e.g., [string1]-[string2].[TLD]). In this section, we describe the part before the first hyphen as a prefix. In conjunction with a well-known subdomain, these prefixes could potentially trick victims. For instance, a casual inspection of the domain irs.gov-addpayment[.]info could trick people into thinking they are navigating to irs[.]gov.\r\n\r\nFigure 3 shows the most popular prefixes of domain names used in the 136,933 root domains we found in this campaign.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161954\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. The 10 most popular prefixes of the root domains found in this campaign.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhile these domains are registered through various registrars, a significant majority (68.06% or 93,197) of the root domains are registered under Dominet (HK) Limited, a registrar based in Hong Kong. The next most popular registrars are Namesilo with 11.85% (16,227) and Gname with 7.94% (10,873) of the root domains.\r\nDomain Registration Trends\r\nThe WHOIS creation dates shown in Figure 4 reveal an interesting shift. We have picked the top 10 most popular domain prefixes in this campaign. The domains with the prefix com- were the most commonly registered in this campaign until May 2025. However, in the past three months, we observed a significant increase in the registration of gov- domains relative to com- domains. This indicates that the campaign is evolving to fit the types of services it impersonates.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161965\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 4. WHOIS creation dates for domains belonging to this campaign.[\/caption]\r\nDomain Lifetimes\r\nWe also evaluated the lifetime of the domains used in this campaign using pDNS data. A domain's lifetime is the duration between its earliest \u201cfirst seen\u201d and latest \u201clast seen\u201d timestamps.\r\n\r\nAs detailed in Figure 5, 39,964 (29.19%) domains were active for two days or less. We saw that 71.3% of these domains were active for less than a week and 82.6% had a lifespan of two weeks or less.\r\n\r\nLess than 6% of domains remain active beyond the first three months of their registration. This rapid churn clearly demonstrates that the campaign's strategy relies on a continuous cycle of newly registered domains to evade detection.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161976\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 5. Distribution of domain lifetimes from pDNS data.[\/caption]\r\nNetwork Infrastructure\r\nAs previously mentioned, the domains involved in these campaigns are highly decentralized. In this section, we investigate the network infrastructure of the campaign.\r\nDNS Infrastructure\r\nThe 194,345 FQDNs in this campaign resolve to a large and diverse set of approximately 43,494 unique IP addresses. The campaign uses a majority of U.S. IP addresses hosted on Autonomous System AS13335, particularly within the 104.21.0[.]0\/16 subnet.\r\n\r\nIn contrast, the nameserver infrastructure is more concentrated, with only 837 unique nameserver root domains. A large majority of the FQDNs use just two providers: AliDNS (45.6%) and Cloudflare (34.6%). This centralization suggests that while the campaign's web hosting is widely distributed, its DNS management is consolidated under a few key services.\r\nCampaign Infrastructure Graph\r\nIn Figure 6, we present an example graph depicting this campaign. We see that there are 90 different root domains pointing to a set of IP addresses in the 104.21.0[.]0\/16 subnet belonging to AS13335. There are several such localized clusters for each IP address and nameserver.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161987\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 6. Campaign graph depicting 90 different root domains pointing to a set of IP addresses within the 104.21.0[.]0\/16 subnet.[\/caption]The U.S. Postal Service (USPS) is the single most impersonated service with 28,045 FQDNs. The broader category of toll services is the most impersonated category in this campaign, with nearly 90,000 dedicated phishing FQDNs.\r\n\r\n We present examples of domains that masquerade as different types of services in the Impersonated Brands and Services section.\r\nGeolocation of the Attack Domains Infrastructure\r\nThe attack domains are hosted on different IP addresses that are geolocated to various countries. To identify the domains generating the most traffic, we analyzed the distribution of pDNS queries to find the DNS query volume for all domains in the campaign.\r\n\r\nWe aggregated the number of DNS responses per domain and geolocated the IP addresses in these responses. Queries to domains located in the U.S. account for more than half the volume of queries, as shown in Figure 7. The attack infrastructure for domains generating the largest volume of traffic were located in the U.S., followed by China and Singapore.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_161998\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 7. Distribution of DNS queries to attack domains by geolocation of the IP addresses.[\/caption]\r\nImpersonated Brands and Services\r\nA large portion of the attack infrastructure we saw was based in the U.S., and the impersonated services reflected this. However, we also identified attackers impersonating services in other countries.\r\nLarge U.S. Focus\r\nThe campaign targets individuals. It sends messages that masquerade as coming from various commercial organizations as well as state and U.S. government offices, such as:\r\n\r\n \tCommercial and state-owned mail and package delivery services\r\n \tState vehicles and licensing agencies\r\n \tState and federal tax services or agencies\r\n\r\nWe also found mentions of U.S. state names and their two-letter abbreviations in the FQDNs.\r\nGlobal Brands and Services\r\n\r\n \tCritical services: This campaign often includes messages that mimic those that could come from critical services such as mail, toll payment services, law enforcement and banking in several countries:\r\n\r\n \tThe U.S. (banking, mail and delivery, tolls)\r\n \tGermany (mail and delivery services, investment banks and savings banks)\r\n \tUnited Arab Emirates (police forces belonging to multiple cities)\r\n \tThe UK (state-owned services)\r\n \tMalaysia, Mexico (banks)\r\n \tArgentina, Australia, Canada, France, Ireland, Israel, Russia (electronic tolls, as well as mail and delivery services).\r\n\r\n\r\n \tGeneral services: The campaign involves impersonating messages from many general services such as:\r\n\r\n \tCarpooling applications\r\n \tOnline platforms for home-sharing and hospitality services\r\n \tPopular social media sites\r\n\r\n\r\n \tTyposquatting: We have observed several FQDNs used in this campaign that are typosquatting popular services, including financial technology applications and personal cloud services\r\n \tE-commerce and online payment platforms: This campaign also impersonates several large e-commerce platforms in:\r\n\r\n \tRussia\r\n \tPoland\r\n \tLithuania\r\n \tOther countries internationally\r\n\r\n\r\n \tCryptocurrency exchanges: We found that the campaign also impersonates cryptocurrency exchanges, wallet and Web3 platforms\r\n \tGaming-related: We have found FQDNs used in this campaign relating to online games and fake marketplaces for in-game skins\r\n\r\nWhat Content Is Being Hosted?\r\nPhishing Impersonating Banking and Popular Services\r\nThe most common landing page we observed contained phishing content impersonating the service indicated by the FQDN. Figure 8 presents examples of phishing pages designed to resemble login and identity verification for a consumer electronics company (5,078 FQDNs) and a significant financial services firm (769 FQDNs). These are potentially aimed at extracting victims\u2019 login information and other sensitive information such as social security numbers.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_162009\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 8. Landing pages for domains phishing banking and popular service providers.[\/caption]\r\nPhishing Impersonating Government Agencies\r\nWe have observed phishing pages impersonating government services such as the IRS and U.S. state vehicle departments and other transportation-related agencies.\r\n\r\nThese landing pages often mention unpaid toll and other service charges. They are potentially aimed at extracting login credentials, personal details and payment information.\r\n\r\nFigure 9 shows examples of landing pages of domains impersonating state-specific electronic toll services. They use the state names and their services in the subdomain names and make use of state logos and emblems within the phishing pages.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_162020\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 9. Landing pages for domains phishing state-specific electronic toll services.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 10 shows examples of landing pages impersonating U.S. government agencies such as the IRS (128 FQDNs). The page contains a fake CAPTCHA page that is designed to manipulate users into executing malicious scripts on their machine.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_162031\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 10. Landing pages for domains phishing government agencies.[\/caption]\r\nMisdelivery and Fake Customs Charges\r\nFigure 11 shows several examples of landing pages containing fake notices of delivery failure, toll violation, international customs charges associated with popular mail and package delivery services, and toll services. These are potentially aimed at extracting personal information such as home addresses, contact details and payment information from victims.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_162042\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 11. Landing pages for misdelivery and fake customs charges.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nWe have uncovered that the smishing campaign impersonating U.S. toll services is not isolated. It is instead a large-scale campaign with global reach impersonating many services across different sectors. The threat is highly decentralized. Attackers are registering and churning through thousands of domains daily.\r\n\r\nTo track this rapidly evolving activity, we developed a multi-faceted intelligence framework that synthesizes data from WHOIS records, pDNS, evolving domain patterns, visual clustering of landing pages and graph-based infrastructure analysis.\r\n\r\nWe advise people to exercise vigilance and caution. People should treat any unsolicited messages from unknown senders with suspicion. We recommend that people verify any request that demands urgent action using the official service provider's website or application. This should be done without clicking any links or calling any phone numbers included in the suspicious message.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:\r\n\r\nAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 00080005045107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n \ticloud.com-remove-device[.]top\r\n \tflde-lity.com-lg[.]icu\r\n \tmichigan.gov-etczhh[.]cc\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

    </head>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Reethika Ramesh" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/reethika-ramesh/">Reethika Ramesh</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Zhanhao Chen" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/zhachenpaloaltonetworks-com/">Zhanhao Chen</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Daiping Liu" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/daiping-liu/">Daiping Liu</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Chi-Wei Liu" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/chi-wei-liu/">Chi-Wei Liu</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Shehroze Farooqi" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/shehroze-farooqi/">Shehroze Farooqi</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Moe Ghasemisharif" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/moe-ghasemisharif/">Moe Ghasemisharif</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>October 23, 2025</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Malware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/">Malware</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:Threat Research" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/">Threat Research</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:phishing" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/">Phishing</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:smishing" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/smishing/">Smishing</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:SMS" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/sms/">SMS</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:social engineering" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/social-engineering/">Social engineering</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-smishing-campaign/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=5f36bb9f85" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>

            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-161931-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>We are attributing an ongoing smishing (phishing via text message) campaign of fraudulent toll violation and package misdelivery notices to a group widely known as the Smishing Triad. Our analysis indicates this campaign is a significantly more extensive and complex threat than previously reported. Attackers have impersonated international services across a wide array of critical sectors.</p>
<p>The attackers have targeted U.S. residents in this campaign since April 2024. The threat actor is evolving their tactics by expanding their reach globally, improving the social engineering tactics used in smishing for delivery.</p>
<p>The threat actor is also expanding the range of services they impersonate to include many international services in critical sectors, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Banking</li>
<li>Cryptocurrency platforms</li>
<li>E-commerce platforms</li>
<li>Healthcare</li>
<li>Law enforcement</li>
<li>Social media</li>
</ul>
<p>The campaign is highly decentralized, lacking a single point of control, and uses a large number of domains and a diverse set of hosting infrastructure. This is advantageous for the attackers as churning through thousands of domains weekly makes detection more difficult.</p>
<p>Using our intelligence framework, we have identified over 194,000 malicious domains linked to this operation since Jan. 1, 2024. Although these domains are registered through a Hong Kong-based registrar and use Chinese nameservers, the attack infrastructure is primarily hosted on popular U.S. cloud services.</p>
<p>This campaign uses SMS messages for social engineering to create a sense of urgency and prompt victims into immediate action. The campaign's global scale, complex infrastructure and realistic phishing pages strongly suggest that it is powered by a large, well-resourced phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) operation. This poses a widespread threat to individuals globally. These phishing pages aim to collect sensitive information such as National Identification Numbers (such as Social Security numbers), home addresses, payment details and login credentials.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 98.6078%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 205.254%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Phishing</b></a><b>, </b><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/sms/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>SMS</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_wven14kmgum2"></a>Technical Analysis of the Extended Smishing Triad Campaign</h2>
<p>Earlier this year, we released timely threat intelligence social posts that reported our discovery of more than <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7303805644812271616/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">10,000 domains involved in smishing scams</a>. Subsequently, we found and <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7321235269012078593/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">blocked over 91,500 domains involved</a> in the same scam. Since publishing those threat intelligence posts, we have continued to track and analyze the threat actors and domains behind these smishing scams.</p>
<p>Security vendor <a href="https://www.resecurity.com/blog/article/Smishing-Triad-Impersonates-Emirates-Post-Target-UAE-Citizens" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Resecurity attributes these attacks</a> to the <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/actor/smishing_triad" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Smishing Triad</a>, reporting that the group shared phishing kits on Telegram and other services. This finding is <a href="https://www.silentpush.com/blog/smishing-triad/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">corroborated by follow-up reports</a> by Silent Push. However, our analysis reveals that the campaign's scope is far broader and evolves faster than previously known.</p>
<p>Many indicators suggest that the campaign is constantly evolving. <a href="https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/phishing-campaign-targeting-mobile-users-in-india-using-india-post-lures" target="_blank" rel="noopener">A Fortinet article</a> highlighted the fact that the threat actors used email-to-SMS features. This article noted that arbitrary email addresses can be used to send messages through iMessage. However, we have observed that more recent smishing messages have started to use phone numbers to send them.</p>
<p>Many of these messages are received from phone numbers beginning with the international country code for the Philippines (+63). However, there has been an increasing number of messages in this campaign received from U.S. phone numbers (+1) as well.</p>
<p>Tracking all domains in this campaign is challenging due to its decentralized nature. The attack domains are short-lived and constantly churned, with thousands registered daily. The rapidly evolving campaign highlights that tracking root domains using just lexical patterns is not enough.</p>
<p>We have developed a multi-faceted intelligence framework to track this campaign. It synthesizes data from the following sources:</p>
<ul>
<li>WHOIS and passive DNS (pDNS) reputation metrics</li>
<li>Evolving domain patterns</li>
<li>Visual clustering of screenshots</li>
<li>Graph-based infrastructure analysis</li>
</ul>
<p>Using our multi-faceted intelligence framework, we found a total of 194,345 fully qualified domain names (<a href="https://www.cloudns.net/blog/fqdn-fully-qualified-domain-name/#:~:text=Conclusion,in%20the%20digital%20domain%20space." target="_blank" rel="noopener">FQDNs</a>) across 136,933 root domains associated with this campaign. These root domains were registered on or after Jan. 1, 2024.</p>
<p>The majority of these domains are registered through Dominet (HK) Limited, a Hong Kong-based registrar and use Chinese nameservers. Although the domain registration and DNS infrastructure originate in China, the attacking infrastructure (the hosting IP addresses) is concentrated in the U.S., particularly within popular cloud services.</p>
<p>We find that the domains in this campaign impersonate global services in many sectors, including:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Critical services:</strong> Banking, healthcare and law enforcement (e.g., multi-national financial services and investment companies, police forces from cities in the Middle East)</li>
<li><strong>Widely used services: </strong>E-commerce, social media, online gaming and cryptocurrency exchanges (e.g., several Russia-based e-commerce markets and cryptocurrency exchanges)</li>
<li><strong>Previously reported services:</strong> Tolls and global state-owned mail and package delivery services extending beyond the U.S. (e.g., Israel, Canada, France, Germany, Ireland, Australia, Argentina)</li>
</ul>
<p>Attackers craft SMS messages to deliver these URLs. These are highly tailored to the victims to compel immediate action. Using social engineering techniques creates a sense of urgency. By employing targeted personal information and incorporating technical or legal jargon they can appear more legitimate. These things combined with the scope of services imitated suggests that a large PhaaS operation is behind this campaign.</p>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_2gpy4kuwsc5w"></a>Underground Phishing-as-a-Service Ecosystem</h2>
<p>In this section, we discuss the underground PhaaS ecosystem and investigate the Smishing Triad Telegram channel. Over the past six months, the channel has evolved from a dedicated phishing kit marketplace into a highly active community that gathers diverse threat actors within the PhaaS ecosystem.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows chat records from different participants within the channel. Most posts are advertising various underground services such as domain registration, data sales and message delivery. Highlighting the intense competition within this ecosystem, multiple threat actors compete to offer the same services, particularly Rich Communication Services and Instant Message delivery (RCS/IM).</p>
<figure id="attachment_161932" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161932" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161932 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-247346-161931-1.png" alt="Screenshot of a Telegram chat with various users discussing services like virtual card provision, RCS/IM delivery, and data brokering, displayed in Chinese characters." width="900" height="675" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-247346-161931-1.png 960w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-247346-161931-1-587x440.png 587w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-247346-161931-1-933x700.png 933w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-247346-161931-1-768x576.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161932" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Telegram chat history of different threat actors in the PhaaS ecosystem.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 2 illustrates below the different roles active in the Smishing Triad Telegram channel and their interactions.</p>
<figure id="attachment_161943" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161943" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161943 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2.png" alt="Diagram illustrating the process of a phishing attack involving various entities such as a Liveness Scanner, Data Broker, Domain Seller Hosting Provider, Blocklist Scanner, SMS/RSC/IM Spammer, and a Phishing Kit Developer. They all work together in the ecosystem developing the target number, phishing message, credentials, and more. Arrows indicate the flow of information and actions between these elements leading to the eventual targeting of a Victim." width="1000" height="1028" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2.png 1993w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2-428x440.png 428w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2-681x700.png 681w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2-768x789.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-251216-161931-2-1495x1536.png 1495w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161943" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. The PhaaS ecosystem of the Smishing Triad.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Threat actors specialize in different stages of the smishing supply chain, enabling them to launch attacks more efficiently and scalably:</p>
<ul>
<li>Upstream
<ul>
<li>Data broker: Sells target phone numbers</li>
<li>Domain seller: Registers disposable domains for hosting phishing websites</li>
<li>Hosting provider: Provides servers to run phishing backends</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Midstream
<ul>
<li>Phishing kit developer: Builds phishing websites (frontend and backend) and maintains the PhaaS platform, including dashboards for harvesting and managing stolen credentials</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Downstream
<ul>
<li>SMS/RCS/IM spammer: Delivers phishing messages at scale to direct victims to phishing websites</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Support
<ul>
<li>Liveness scanner: Verifies which target phone numbers are valid and active</li>
<li>Blocklist scanner: Checks the phishing domains against blocklists to trigger asset rotations</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_3n47xuqs7yfq"></a>Domains Involved in the Campaign</h2>
<p>A majority of the root domains involved in this campaign were created with a hyphenated series of strings followed by a top-level domain (TLD) (e.g., [<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">string1</span>]-[<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">string2</span>].[<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">TLD</span>]). In this section, we describe the part before the first hyphen as a prefix. In conjunction with a well-known subdomain, these prefixes could potentially trick victims. For instance, a casual inspection of the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">irs.gov-addpayment[.]info</span> could trick people into thinking they are navigating to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">irs[.]gov</span>.</p>
<p>Figure 3 shows the most popular prefixes of domain names used in the 136,933 root domains we found in this campaign.</p>
<figure id="attachment_161954" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161954" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161954 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart.png" alt="Pie chart showing domain distribution: 80.0% .COM, 8.7% .GOVE, 5.9% .ORG, 1.9% .DE, 2.0% all other domains below 1%." width="1000" height="673" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-654x440.png 654w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1040x700.png 1040w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-768x517.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1536x1034.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161954" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. The 10 most popular prefixes of the root domains found in this campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<p>While these domains are registered through various registrars, a significant majority (68.06% or 93,197) of the root domains are registered under Dominet (HK) Limited, a registrar based in Hong Kong. The next most popular registrars are Namesilo with 11.85% (16,227) and Gname with 7.94% (10,873) of the root domains.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_jv258gtsa30n"></a>Domain Registration Trends</h3>
<p>The WHOIS creation dates shown in Figure 4 reveal an interesting shift. We have picked the top 10 most popular domain prefixes in this campaign. The domains with the prefix <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">com-</span> were the most commonly registered in this campaign until May 2025. However, in the past three months, we observed a significant increase in the registration of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">gov-</span> domains relative to com- domains. This indicates that the campaign is evolving to fit the types of services it impersonates.</p>
<figure id="attachment_161965" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161965" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161965 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-259965-161931-4.png" alt="Bar graph displaying the number of domains by WHOIS creation month from October 2024 to June 2025, segmented by domain prefixes including al, ca, co, com, de, dmv, gov, id, ny, and org. The highest domain count is in March 2025 for the 'all' category with close to 30k domains." width="1000" height="422" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-259965-161931-4.png 1245w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-259965-161931-4-786x331.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-259965-161931-4-768x324.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161965" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. WHOIS creation dates for domains belonging to this campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_p2jxsfqnzoqs"></a>Domain Lifetimes</h3>
<p>We also evaluated the lifetime of the domains used in this campaign using pDNS data. A domain's lifetime is the duration between its earliest “first seen” and latest “last seen” timestamps.</p>
<p>As detailed in Figure 5, 39,964 (29.19%) domains were active for two days or less. We saw that 71.3% of these domains were active for less than a week and 82.6% had a lifespan of two weeks or less.</p>
<p>Less than 6% of domains remain active beyond the first three months of their registration. This rapid churn clearly demonstrates that the campaign's strategy relies on a continuous cycle of newly registered domains to evade detection.</p>
<figure id="attachment_161976" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161976" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161976 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-262783-161931-5.png" alt="Bar chart showing the distribution of domain lifespans, with 'Count of Domains' on the vertical axis and 'Number of Days Domains Were Active' on the horizontal axis. The chart indicates a high count of domains with very short lifespans, decreasing sharply as the number of active days increases. Most domains were active for less than 10 days." width="1000" height="500" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-262783-161931-5.png 1200w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-262783-161931-5-786x393.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-262783-161931-5-768x384.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161976" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Distribution of domain lifetimes from pDNS data.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_6sx7y6em8oeo"></a>Network Infrastructure</h2>
<p>As previously mentioned, the domains involved in these campaigns are highly decentralized. In this section, we investigate the network infrastructure of the campaign.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_syn98mepr8uk"></a>DNS Infrastructure</h3>
<p>The 194,345 FQDNs in this campaign resolve to a large and diverse set of approximately 43,494 unique IP addresses. The campaign uses a majority of U.S. IP addresses hosted on Autonomous System AS13335, particularly within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.21.0[.]0/16</span> subnet.</p>
<p>In contrast, the nameserver infrastructure is more concentrated, with only 837 unique nameserver root domains. A large majority of the FQDNs use just two providers: AliDNS (45.6%) and Cloudflare (34.6%). This centralization suggests that while the campaign's web hosting is widely distributed, its DNS management is consolidated under a few key services.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_h1uq4wgneddx"></a>Campaign Infrastructure Graph</h3>
<p>In Figure 6, we present an example graph depicting this campaign. We see that there are 90 different root domains pointing to a set of IP addresses in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.21.0[.]0/16</span> subnet belonging to AS13335. There are several such localized clusters for each IP address and nameserver.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_161987" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161987" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161987 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6.png" alt="Network diagram depicting various types of internet connections between a central node and multiple outer nodes, with icons representing different components like URLs, hostnames, and IP addresses, accompanied by a legend explaining the symbols used. URL icon is URL. FILE icon is file. WWW earth icon is hostname. American flag is IP address. Hostname icon in orange circle is domain in a seed list. Blue indicates relationships." width="1000" height="1070" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6.png 1914w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6-411x440.png 411w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6-654x700.png 654w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6-768x822.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-265483-161931-6-1436x1536.png 1436w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161987" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Campaign graph depicting 90 different root domains pointing to a set of IP addresses within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.21.0[.]0/16</span> subnet.</figcaption></figure>The U.S. Postal Service (USPS) is the single most impersonated service with 28,045 FQDNs. The broader category of toll services is the most impersonated category in this campaign, with nearly 90,000 dedicated phishing FQDNs.</p>
<p><a id="post-161931-_2yfao5sixyom"></a> We present examples of domains that masquerade as different types of services in the <a href="#post-161931-_xluz304bv5pn" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Impersonated Brands and Services</a> section.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_ist1p2e25q2m"></a>Geolocation of the Attack Domains Infrastructure</h3>
<p>The attack domains are hosted on different IP addresses that are geolocated to various countries. To identify the domains generating the most traffic, we analyzed the distribution of pDNS queries to find the DNS query volume for all domains in the campaign.</p>
<p>We aggregated the number of DNS responses per domain and geolocated the IP addresses in these responses. Queries to domains located in the U.S. account for more than half the volume of queries, as shown in Figure 7. The attack infrastructure for domains generating the largest volume of traffic were located in the U.S., followed by China and Singapore.</p>
<figure id="attachment_161998" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-161998" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-161998 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1.png" alt="Bar chart displaying the percentage distribution of DNS queries across countries. United States leads at 58%, followed by China at 21%, Singapore at 19%, all other countries combined at 1.5%, and Germany at 0.5%. The chart includes labels for each country and percentage values on each bar." width="1000" height="619" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1-711x440.png 711w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1-1131x700.png 1131w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1-768x475.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/chart-1-1536x950.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-161998" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Distribution of DNS queries to attack domains by geolocation of the IP addresses.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_xluz304bv5pn"></a>Impersonated Brands and Services</h2>
<p>A large portion of the attack infrastructure we saw was based in the U.S., and the impersonated services reflected this. However, we also identified attackers impersonating services in other countries.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_vdobhug0urz4"></a>Large U.S. Focus</h3>
<p>The campaign targets individuals. It sends messages that masquerade as coming from various commercial organizations as well as state and U.S. government offices, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Commercial and state-owned mail and package delivery services</li>
<li>State vehicles and licensing agencies</li>
<li>State and federal tax services or agencies</li>
</ul>
<p>We also found mentions of U.S. state names and their two-letter abbreviations in the FQDNs.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_na2iqt9bb3wm"></a>Global Brands and Services</h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Critical services</strong>: This campaign often includes messages that mimic those that could come from critical services such as mail, toll payment services, law enforcement and banking in several countries:
<ul>
<li>The U.S. (banking, mail and delivery, tolls)</li>
<li>Germany (mail and delivery services, investment banks and savings banks)</li>
<li>United Arab Emirates (police forces belonging to multiple cities)</li>
<li>The UK (state-owned services)</li>
<li>Malaysia, Mexico (banks)</li>
<li>Argentina, Australia, Canada, France, Ireland, Israel, Russia (electronic tolls, as well as mail and delivery services).</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>General services</strong>: The campaign involves impersonating messages from many general services such as:
<ul>
<li>Carpooling applications</li>
<li>Online platforms for home-sharing and hospitality services</li>
<li>Popular social media sites</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Typosquatting</strong>: We have observed several FQDNs used in this campaign that are typosquatting popular services, including financial technology applications and personal cloud services</li>
<li><strong>E-commerce and online payment platforms</strong>: This campaign also impersonates several large e-commerce platforms in:
<ul>
<li>Russia</li>
<li>Poland</li>
<li>Lithuania</li>
<li>Other countries internationally</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Cryptocurrency exchanges</strong>: We found that the campaign also impersonates cryptocurrency exchanges, wallet and Web3 platforms</li>
<li><strong>Gaming-related</strong>: We have found FQDNs used in this campaign relating to online games and fake marketplaces for in-game skins</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_g3m3royesyqm"></a>What Content Is Being Hosted?</h2>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_s34dvvjny6re"></a>Phishing Impersonating Banking and Popular Services</h3>
<p>The most common landing page we observed contained phishing content impersonating the service indicated by the FQDN. Figure 8 presents examples of phishing pages designed to resemble login and identity verification for a consumer electronics company (5,078 FQDNs) and a significant financial services firm (769 FQDNs). These are potentially aimed at extracting victims’ login information and other sensitive information such as social security numbers.</p>
<figure id="attachment_162009" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-162009" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-162009 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8.jpeg" alt="Two open browser windows displaying user interface designs for account access. The left screen shows a login page with options to enter an email address, and buttons for password recovery and account creation. The right screen displays a form for identity verification requiring name, date of birth, and identification number." width="1000" height="535" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8-786x421.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8-1308x700.jpeg 1308w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8-768x411.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-276802-161931-8-1536x822.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-162009" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Landing pages for domains phishing banking and popular service providers.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_nn2ywxkm9rvr"></a>Phishing Impersonating Government Agencies</h3>
<p>We have observed phishing pages impersonating government services such as the IRS and U.S. state vehicle departments and other transportation-related agencies.</p>
<p>These landing pages often mention unpaid toll and other service charges. They are potentially aimed at extracting login credentials, personal details and payment information.</p>
<p>Figure 9 shows examples of landing pages of domains impersonating state-specific electronic toll services. They use the state names and their services in the subdomain names and make use of state logos and emblems within the phishing pages.</p>
<figure id="attachment_162020" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-162020" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-162020 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9.jpeg" alt="Left: Photo of vehicles driving on a snowy highway during winter above text spoofing a department of transportation website. Right: Screenshot of the &quot;Renewal Express&quot; website interface for vehicle registration, featuring a section titled &quot;To pay your notice.&quot; In both images some of the information is redacted." width="1000" height="537" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9-786x422.jpeg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9-1304x700.jpeg 1304w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9-768x412.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-279886-161931-9-1536x824.jpeg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-162020" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Landing pages for domains phishing state-specific electronic toll services.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 10 shows examples of landing pages impersonating U.S. government agencies such as the IRS (128 FQDNs). The page contains a fake CAPTCHA page that is designed to manipulate users into executing malicious scripts on their machine.</p>
<figure id="attachment_162031" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-162031" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-162031 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10.png" alt="Left: Two people smiling while looking at a laptop screen, displayed with a &quot;Robot or human?&quot; CAPTCHA prompt. Right: A close-up of a computer screen showing a Google reCAPTCHA verification step." width="1000" height="387" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10-786x304.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10-1810x700.png 1810w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10-768x297.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-283082-161931-10-1536x594.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-162031" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Landing pages for domains phishing government agencies.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_nzoykzv7xwdm"></a>Misdelivery and Fake Customs Charges</h3>
<p>Figure 11 shows several examples of landing pages containing fake notices of delivery failure, toll violation, international customs charges associated with popular mail and package delivery services, and toll services. These are potentially aimed at extracting personal information such as home addresses, contact details and payment information from victims.</p>
<figure id="attachment_162042" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-162042" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-162042 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11.jpeg" alt="Collage of four website screenshots including a UK Government customs charge page, a Hebrew mobile app interface, a delivery options page, and a shipping tracker page. " width="1000" height="1039" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11.jpeg 1971w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11-423x440.jpeg 423w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11-674x700.jpeg 674w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11-768x798.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-286816-161931-11-1478x1536.jpeg 1478w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-162042" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Landing pages for misdelivery and fake customs charges.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>We have uncovered that the smishing campaign impersonating U.S. toll services is not isolated. It is instead a large-scale campaign with global reach impersonating many services across different sectors. The threat is highly decentralized. Attackers are registering and churning through thousands of domains daily.</p>
<p>To track this rapidly evolving activity, we developed a multi-faceted intelligence framework that synthesizes data from WHOIS records, pDNS, evolving domain patterns, visual clustering of landing pages and graph-based infrastructure analysis.</p>
<p>We advise people to exercise vigilance and caution. People should treat any unsolicited messages from unknown senders with suspicion. We recommend that people verify any request that demands urgent action using the official service provider's website or application. This should be done without clicking any links or calling any phone numbers included in the suspicious message.</p>
<h3><a id="post-161931-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<p><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-161931-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">icloud.com-remove-device[.]top</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">flde-lity.com-lg[.]icu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">michigan.gov-etczhh[.]cc</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">utah.gov-etcfr[.]win</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">irs.gov-tax[.]cfd</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">irs.org.gov-tax[.]icu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">anpost.com-pay[.]online</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kveesh6.il-363[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dhl.de-yiore[.]store</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">usps.com-posewxts[.]top</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">israeipost.co-ykk[.]vip</span></li>

				<h3>Tags</h3><ul role="list"><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/" role="link" title="phishing" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:tags:phishing">Phishing</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/smishing/" role="link" title="smishing" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:tags:smishing">Smishing</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/sms/" role="link" title="SMS" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:tags:SMS">SMS</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/social-engineering/" role="link" title="social engineering" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="global-smishing-campaign:tags:social engineering">Social engineering</a></li></ul>
			</div> 
              <div class="be__post-nav">
